ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CITIZENSHIP
(Applications from non-citizen members of family)


    1. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour whether the Government will give sympathetic consideration to an application for citizenship from an applicant who is the sole remaining non-citizen member of his family.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the general policy on citizenship was enunciated by the Minister in this House on the 21st of May, 1968. However, the Government is prepared to give sympathetic consideration to such applications provided the applicants satisfy the provisions of Article 57 (1) of the Singapore Constitution.

    Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon (Tiong Bahru)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, the Government is very strict as regards the approval of citizenship applications. Normally, an applicant who can fulfil residential and other qualifications is granted citizenship. But now the Government will have to consider whether he is likely to contribute economically to the state and, because of

Column: 443

this, it is very difficult to have applications for citizenship approved. I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary --

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ch'ng, are you going to ask a supplementary question?

    Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon(In Mandarin): Yes, Sir. Can the Parliamentary Secretary say whether Government's policy on applications for citizenship will be revised?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have indicated just now that sympathetic consideration will be given to applications for citizenship. But as far as the policy is concerned, it is constantly under review.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, we are aware of Government's difficulty on the issue of citizenship certificates to applicants at this particular time. But, all the same, as there are many applicants waiting for citizenship, can the Parliamentary Secretary say whether Government will issue a statement to the effect that for a period of, say, so many years, there is no need for people to apply for citizenship as we will not be able to give them citizenship, so that they need not waste their time?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, I do not think that would be practical. For example, people who apply for citizenship at the present time do not get their applications approved. But if they had applied, say, five years ago, their applications would have been approved. Therefore, it is almost impossible to lay down such a policy as indicated by the Member for Bras Basah.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, can the Government say what sympathetic grounds are required so that applicants for citizenship can prepare to meet these requirements?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, there are many different shades of people and character in this world. It is almost impossible to lay down anything definite. Just look

Column: 444

at the Gentlemen across the Floor. Each Member has a different background and each has a different face. So how are we going to lay down the rules as to whom we will give sympathetic consideration?

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, is it to be understood that the Government does not know what type of hardship can be considered as genuine grounds for sympathetic consideration?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, I can only say that each case will have to be considered on its own merits.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary say whether Government will give sympathetic consideration to applicants whose parents, brothers and sisters are all Singapore citizens? There is one case where, because the applicant was born during the Japanese occupation, he is unable to get his citizenship papers.

    Another point relates to applicants who were told in 1964 not to apply for citizenship by the authorities concerned when we were in Malaysia. Now that they want to apply for citizenship, they cannot get their applications approved. Can the Parliamentary Secretary give sympathetic consideration to these cases?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, the first question of the Member for Paya Lebar was asked by the Member for Mountbatten, and I have already answered it.

    As regards the second question, I do not think there is any proof that individuals were told in 1964 not to apply. Even if that were so, the case will still have to be considered on its own merits.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister enunicated the policy on citizenship on 21st May. 1968. It is now nearly two years and things in Singapore have improved a lot. In view of the rapid growth of the economy of Singapore, does the Government not think that it is now the opportune time to review the policy on

Column: 445

citizenship so that more people can be productive and help to contribute to the prosperity of Singapore?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, as I said just now, the policy on citizenship is always under constant review.

    Mr Lee Teck Him (Ulu Pandan)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, on the question of citizenship, I feel that the Government's policy is wrong.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Lee, are you asking a supplementary question or are you embarking on a debate?

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, what I meant to say was that the Government should revise its policy on citizenship and certain officials should be appointed for this task. I know of certain applicants who should qualify for citizenship.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Lee, can you please ask a supplementary question?

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, I want to ask a supplementary question and also give my comments on the Government's policy on citizenship. The policy should be reviewed, and, where possible, citizenship should be granted straightaway without the Criminal Investigation Department investigating to see how many wives an applicant has and so on.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid the Member is not asking a supplementary question at all. He is, in fact, giving a speech.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Lee, will you please ask your supplementary question?

    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, what I was asking is an indirect question. Is it true that applicants with more than one wife do not qualify for citizenship?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I really do not know what the Member wants. If he says that we should give citizenship to a man with many wives, I do not think that is relevant. That could be a disqualification. As I said, we have to look into every aspect of the individual.

Column: 446



    Mr Lee Teck Him(In Mandarin): Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary mean that a person with many wives is not qualified to be a citizen? As we are not debating this question, I suggest that the policy on citizenship should be reviewed.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta): Mr Speaker, Sir, during my meet-the-people sessions, I receive many cases of applications for citizenship made years ago. They were informed by letter that their applications had been refused and were told to reapply again. But when they reapplied, the Registry of Citizenship did not accept their applications. Can the Parliamentary Secretary explain why their applications were not accepted when they had been told to reapply again?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, the circumstances of an individual change all the time. Several years ago, a person might not qualify for citizenship. If he were to reapply now, the circumstances might be different. He may now be a millionaire or a manufacturer or an industrialist. So the circumstances are different. Therefore, when we ask an applicant to reapply, it means that we will reassess his present situation to see whether he qualifies for citizenship.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, that being the case, then those who apply for citizenship will be refused until they become millionaires. I do not think that is the proper answer.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: What I actually meant was that this applies to a person who can really make a definite contribution to the country. This is the policy enunciated by the Minister in May 1968.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary said that when a person has made no contribution to the state, he will not get his citizenship papers. But labour has contributed much to Singapore. So how can he say that a labourer has not made any contribution?

Column: 447



    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I did not say that a labourer does not qualify for citizenship at all.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): That particular point, I think, has caused a bit of inconvenience. I am just wondering whether it would not be best, when sending out this letter of refusal, to indicate that if the personal circumstances of the applicant have changed, he may reapply. If there have been no changes, he may forget about reapplication. That will save a bit of inconvenience.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, that again is not practical, because, as I indicated earlier, the policy is under constant review.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong: I would like to ask this question. If the applicant reapplies, will the Government ensure that he will get his citizenship?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: No, Sir, but consideration will be given to such an application.

OFFICIAL PUBLICATIONS
(Mailing to Singapore students abroad)


    2. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour whether official publications and other informative materials such as "The Mirror", etc, are being mailed regularly to our students abroad from the Republic's missions overseas, so as to keep them informed of current affairs in Singapore.

    The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Inche A. Rahim Ishak) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, our students abroad are normally kept informed of current developments in the Republic through official publications distributed by our overseas missions. In addition to the Mirror, there is also the publication called Berita Pelajar, published by the Public Service Commission. A number of our overseas missions also publish the Singapore Newsletter which is distributed among students as well. Such publications are

Column: 448

sent sometimes on request by individual students, or to student organisations or groups who share them. Besides these publications, some Singapore daily newspapers are available in the missions for students to read. It may well be that official publications do not reach all students, but where requests are made by individuals or groups of students, every effort is made to meet their requirements.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister of State for Foreign Affairs be able to indicate the number of copies of such publications that are mailed to our overseas missions?

    Inche Rahim Ishak: Mr Speaker. Sir, as the Member for Punggol has asked for this information, he will get it. The number of copies of the Mirror distributed to students in Australia is 180. This distribution started in 1969, and copies of the Mirror are distributed by the Ministry of Culture.

    This is the alphabetical order of distribution, in Cambodia, as no students are registered with our Embassy there, we do not send any copies of the Mirror. In Canada, 89 copies. In Hong Kong, no students are registered with the Singapore Commission there, so we do not send them any. In India, 12 copies of the Mirror are distributed, and these copies are shared among the students, as the mailing list of 200 has to include Government offices in India and diplomatic missions. In Indonesia, no copies are distributed, although 11 students in Soerabaya and Jogjakarta have recently registered with the Singapore Embassy and they will be receiving the Mirror in due course. In Japan, 51 copies of the Mirror are sent directly by the Ministry of Culture. Figures are not available for Malaysia. In New Zealand, 214 copies of the Mirror are sent, and this figure includes some New Zealand and Malaysian students who want them. In the Philippines, there is no circulation because no students have as yet registered with the Singapore Embassy In Thailand, there is no circulation.

Column: 449



    Publications available to students registered with the Singapore Embassy: the United Arab Republic, no circulation. Until January 1969, the Mirror was distributed in that country but now it has been replaced by the Singapore Newsletter issued by our Embassy in Cairo. In the United Kingdom and Eire, there are 387 copies of the Mirror in London alone and 391 copies in the other provinces in the U.K., giving a total of 778 copies. In the United States of America, 82 copies of the Mirror are distributed.

    For the information of the Member for Punggol, all our missions issue the Singapore Newsletter twice a month, except those in Kuala Lumpur, Jakarta and Manila.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: The Minister of State has mentioned that in Australia the Mirror was distributed in 1969. However, he could not indicate the date of distribution for the other missions which he named. I wonder whether he could enlighten this House on it.

    Inche A. Rahim Ishak: Mr Speaker, Sir, here is a straightforward answer to a straightforward question. It could have been before or after 1969.

    As to the second part of the question by the Member for Punggol. I think he has not yet returned to be an overseas student; he is still a Member of Parliament.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Is the Minister of State able to indicate that these copies are really being distributed, because when I was in some of our foreign missions, I found that a lot of such copies had not been distributed.

    Inche Rahim Ishak: Mr Speaker, Sir, unless the Member for Punggol wants to split hairs and discuss the meaning of the word "distribution", I do not see the purpose of his question, except that, as I said earlier, some students get copies of the Mirror directly as they are sent direct by the Ministry of Culture. Some get them in their hostels or dor

Column: 450

mitories or in the reading-rooms of our missions abroad and in other places where they get together.

SCHOOL CHILDREN
(Production of documents at beginning of school year)


    3. Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap asked the Minister for Education why school children who have been attending a school for a few years are required to produce documents such as birth certificates, parents' identity cards and citizenship certificates at the beginning of each subsequent school year.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am asked by my Minister to reply. This Ministry has always been aware that parents are greatly inconvenienced and are concerned whenever their children are required to produce important documents for verification by schools. There is no ruling that such documents have to be produced annually for inspection. On the contrary, schools have been repeatedly advised by circular to refrain from asking for documents, except in the case of new admissions or where the pupil's eligibility for remission of school fees is in doubt. Even then, only the minimum number of documents will be called for and the reason for doing so is explained to the parents concerned.

    Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap (Geylang Serai)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister consider changing this system and, instead, issue forms to the parents of the students so that the required particulars can be filled in by them? This will ensure that the documents are not lost.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Even if forms are distributed to parents for entry, they have to be verified by the schools concerned. Therefore, the documents have to be required by the school principals.

PRE-UNIVERSITY CLASSES IN
SEMBAWANG AND NEE SOON
SECONDARY SCHOOLS


    4. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Education whether he will consider the conducting of pre-university classes in any one of the three secondary schools in the Sembawang and Nee Soon Constituencies for students residing in those Constituencies who have completed their secondary education.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Sir, our policy is to centralise Pre-University education as far as possible so that our limited resources of specialist teachers, teaching aids and other facilities may be used to the maximum advantage.

    At present, Pre-University education is available in the National Junior College and in 44 Government and Government-Aided secondary schools.

    The three secondary schools in the Sembawang and Nee Soon Constituencies had a combined enrolment of 834 Secondary Four students in 1969, of whom about 100 are expected to qualify for admission to Pre-University classes in 1970. In view of the need to distribute them according to language media and in Arts and Science courses, four Pre-University I classes would have to be formed for this small number of students, each class having an average enrolment of only about 20 students. This is not an economically-sized class to run, and there is therefore no case for setting up a Pre-University centre within the two constituencies. All the 100 students will be found places in Pre-University classes as close to their homes as possible.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to the reply given by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, it is not possible to set up a Pre-University class in the two constituencies in question because of the small number of students. I hope that in future when the number of students increases, the Parliamentary Secretary

Column: 452

will reconsider the question of setting, up Pre-University classes.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng: Mr Speaker, Sir, when there is an increase of enrolment of students, we will consider the question of setting up Pre-University classes in these two constituencies.

EXTRA-CURRICULAR
ACTIVITIES RECORD CARDS FOR
SECONDARY SCHOOL STUDENTS
(Particulars)


    5. Mr N. Govindasamy asked the Minister for Education (a) when his Ministry decided to introduce Extra-Curricular Activities Record Cards for students in secondary schools, and what is the cost involved in some of the schools for printing those cards; (b) whether any officer or group of officers were assigned by his Ministry to work out the details for the implementation of such a scheme; and, if not, what arrangements have been made to ensure the uniformity in the maintenance of such records in every secondary school; (c) why his Ministry considers it not necessary to issue a circular when introducing such an important scheme; and (d) what steps have been taken to rectify the confusion that has been created among the principals and staffs of secondary schools by conflicting telephone instructions on the introduction and subsequent cancellation and reintroduction of such scheme.

    Dr Lee Chiaw Meng (for the Minister for Education): Sir, it is regretted that a certain amount of confusion arose over the introduction and subsequent suspension of the use of cards to mark the attendance of pupils at extra-curricular activities. The original intention was to introduce a system of recording attendance without involving expenditure for a trial period, at the end of which a decision would be taken whether a standardised printed card should be introduced. Only then would a circular on the subject be issued to schools. Unfortunately, owing to the lack of precise instructions, there was confusion over the conduct of the experiment and.

Column: 453

a telephone message had to be relayed to schools to suspend the trial use of attendance cards pending further instructions.

    The Physical Education Advisory Committee of my Ministry is currently studying the problem and reviewing the whole scheme of awarding marks for extra-curricular activities. The revised scheme will ensure that, whilst pupils are encouraged to participate in a variety of extra-curricular activities, there is no excessive participation at the expense of their academic achievement and progress. Marks will be awarded fairly to reflect the effort put in and the quality of the performance. Such marks will be recorded in the report books of the pupils and converted into grades. The final grades obtained in extra-curricular activities in Secondary Four can be used in place of the grades obtained in an academic subject in the School Certificate Examination for purposes of applying for admission to Pre-University classes.

CRASH HELMETS
(Action against price increase)


    6. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Communications whether and what action has been or is being taken against unscrupulous vendors who have unreasonably raised the price of crash helmets since the introduction of legislation making it compulsory for the holder of a provisional licence to wear a crash helmet while driving a motorcycle.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no intention on the part of my Ministry to control either the import or sale price of crash helmets at present, as there are more than adequate stocks in Singapore to meet the known demands. We will let the law of supply and demand take its natural course.

    The Singapore Institute of Standards and Industrial Research (SISIR), which is the responsible authority for testing and approving crash helmets, have sample-tested consignments totalling

Column: 454

30,000 crash helmets over the last l½ years, and 26,841 or 90 per cent have been approved for sale in Singapore. Whilst the number of provisional licence holders of motor cycles and motor scooters who are required by law to wear crash helmets as from the 1st of last month is only 14,000, the number of new applications for such provisional licences is estimated at around 1,000 per month.

    It is pertinent to point out that the necessity to get SISIR's approval before crash helmets are permitted to be put on sale in Singapore adds only an average of 60 cents to the imported cost per helmet. If the consignments are larger, the cost of sampling-tests would go down even lower.

POLITICAL PARTIES IN
SINGAPORE
(Compliance with Societies Act)


    7. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Defence how many political parties there are in Singapore at present and how many of them have not complied with the Societies Act.

    The Minister for Defence (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are altogether 13 political associations registered in Singapore.

    As to the second part of the question, it is presumed that it refers to noncompliance with the requirements of the Societies Act with respect to a political association, namely, amend its rules to provide for its membership to be confined to Singapore citizens, and/or change its name if it is the same as that of an organisation outside Singapore, and/or change its symbol if it is the same as that of an organisation outside Singapore. If that is the case, Sir, there are six political associations which have not complied with one or more of these requirements.

    Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson)(In Mandarin): Sir, will the Minister be able to give the names of the six political associations which have not complied with the Societies Act?

Column: 455



    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the six political parties are: the Barisan Sosialis Party, the U.P.P. (United People's Party), the Workers' Party, Parti Kesatuan Ra'ayat (United Democratic Party), Parti Rakyat Singapore State Division, Persatuan Islam Setanah Melayu, Singapore (Pan-Malayan Islamic Party, Singapore).

    Mr Ang Nam Piau(In Mandarin): Sir, why have these six political parties not complied with the Societies Act? And why does the Government not close them down?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think some of them, are already dormant. As for the others, I do not know why they do not comply. But I can assure Members that they are under very constant and close surveillance. Whether any action will be taken against them will depend on our assessment of whether by their own madness they liquidate themselves, or by their mad acts they become a danger to society and to this country.

SINGAPORE FISHING BOATS
(Protection against pirates)


    8. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Defence what steps he proposes to take for the protection of Singapore fishing boats against pirates on the high seas.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, this matter was raised in Parliament by the Member for Jurong on the 24th January, 1968. I refer Members to Hansard, Vol. 26, cols. 1094-6, for the detailed reply by the then Minister of State for Defence. To refresh the memory of Members. I would like to say that in his reply to the question at that time, the Member for Sepoy Lines stated that the Marine Police were unable to afford protection to Singapore fishing vessels operating far away in international waters.

    I have to report that the position has not changed very much since then. However, with the build-up of the Air Defence Command and the Maritime Command of the Singapore Armed

Column: 456

Forces, it is envisaged that some degree of assistance may be available in the not too distant future.

POLICE PROCEDURE FOR
IDENTIFICATION OF
DEAD PERSONS
(Particulars)


    9. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Defence (a) what procedure is adopted by the Police when carrying out investigations to identify a dead person found by them; (b) what form of liaison the Police maintain with the hospitals to ensure that the next-of-kin can claim a corpse from a hospital mortuary in the most satisfactory manner; and (c) if he will ensure that the Police will contact and inform the family of a deceased person without fail where the identity of that person has been established.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, in reply to the first part of the question, I will say that where there are means of identification of the body, the Police will then immediately inform the next-of-kin of the deceased. If no means of identification are available, then the list of persons reported missing is checked while, at the same time, an appeal is made through the press for assistance in identification from members of the public.

    Where the identity of the dead person cannot be established after a lapse of four days, the body is disposed of by the Government. Particulars relating to the dead body, however, are kept for purposes of record.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is constant liaison between the hospital authorities and the Police through the Police post at the Outram Road General Hospital. The Police post receives as well as disseminates information regarding sudden deaths, or deaths brought about by violence, or deaths in which the cause is unknown. After investigation, the Police will contact and inform the next-of-kin of the deceased. The Gross Domestic Product is a close relative of the G.N.P., or Gross National Product, and differs from it only in that the G.N.P, includes earnings of Singapore citizens from overseas sources and excludes earnings in Singapore accruing to persons and corporations abroad. Taxation Policy

    This concludes my observations on the Ordinary and Development Estimates. Before I go on to discuss possible future courses our economy may take, I should say a few words on taxation policy. The Government's policy in recent years has been to depend on fast economic expansion and improved tax administration to provide increased revenue rather than raise

Column: 502

rates of taxation to higher levels or introduce new taxes. Last year, some minor tax increases as well as new taxes were announced to meet the rising needs of our defence build-up. 1969 revenue increased by $131.5 million over 1968. The yield of new revenue measures was $30.4 million while economic expansion contributed most of the balance of $101.0 million.

    Treasury estimates of tax yields, as set out in the Estimates and explained in the Treasury paper, indicate that increasing yields, resulting from economic growth, will be adequate to meet expenditure increases. I therefore do not propose to raise new taxes, apart from the recent increase in tobacco duties to bring them in line with Malaysia. Singapore, contrary to the belief of many Backbenchers, is a lightly taxed country. Tax revenues amount to about 13 per cent of G.N.P. In other countries they are much higher, as much as 30 per cent or more of G.N.P. in some instances. So long as we maintain a robust rate of economic expansion and maintain government expenditure to essentials, we need not emulate the example of these highly taxed countries.

The Near Future

    With this glad news to the taxpayer out of the way, I turn to look at our immediate economic prospects. It is important that we should not be lulled into a sense of false security by the mild boom now going on. There are dark clouds on the horizon, and it is as well that we prepare for more difficult times. The first adverse factor affecting our economy over the next two years will be the completion of the British military withdrawal by 31st December, 1971. In the next three years, the economy of Singapore will feel the impact of a decline of British military expenditure, from $415 million in 1969 to zero in 1972. There is likely to be a reduction of some $100 million to $150 million for this year and a final phasing out of the remaining $250 million to $300 million in 1971. While no longer the catastrophe we once feared they would be, declines of expenditure of

Column: 503

this magnitude cannot but have an unpleasant impact on our economy. In 1969, the reduction was estimated at some $40 million and was hardly felt.

    As regards world trade which, as we have repeatedly seen, influences our economy significantly, it is unlikely to provide the substantial impetus to growth which it did in the years 1968 and 1969. In these two years, world trade expanded at unprecedented rates, 11 per cent and 14 per cent respectively. There is likely to be a slowing down of world trade in 1970. The extent of this is yet uncertain.

    Much of this uncertainty derives from the outlook of the U.S. economy for this year. The American economy is so large and powerful that fluctuations in its level of activity exercise a strong influence on the economies of the rest of the world outside the Communist bloc. For just over two years, the American administration, in the last year of President Johnson and the first year of President Nixon, has been battling with the problems of domestic inflation and unsettled balance of payments position. The l960s have seen a sustained and powerful growth of the U.S. economy, the G.N.P. increasing from U.S. $503 billion in 1960 to U.S. $932 billion in 1969. In the last four years of the decade, as the American economy approached and reached the level of full employment, inflationary pressures began to build up. These pressures became grave, when military expenditure in Vietnam was substantially increased as from 1967.

    With domestic price inflation there has also occurred the inevitable concomitant - a squeeze on the balance of payments. Whereas, throughout the 1950s and the first half of the 1960s, the American balance of payments on trading account invariably showed an annual surplus of anything between U.S. $3 billion and $5 billion a year, the last year or two has seen this reduced to very small amounts, quite inadequate to support the large overseas payments on account of American capital invest-

    Since December 1968, the Federal Reserve Board has begun a policy of severe credit restraint. Because of the strength and power of the American economy, it was only in the last few months that the tight money policy of the Federal Reserve Board has produced visible results. There have been significant reductions in the volume of industrial production, in the volume of new construction, in expenditure on consumer durables and a small increase in unemployment. They do not see any recession of significant proportions. They expect price inflation to moderate from the annual rate of 54 per cent last year to around 4 per cent or 44 per cent this year. They expect the economy to pick up momentum in the second half of this year.

The Longer-term Perspective

    I now turn to the longer-term perspective, looking to the mid '70s and beyond. Unless the stability of the area is seriously upset, it is likely that we can sustain and even increase the momentum of industrial growth which we recently achieved. The Promotion Centres established by the Economic Development Board in Europe and America and Japan have gained good experience in the last few years. Unless we see a world depression developing on some scale - and the consensus among the experts is that this is an improbable eventuality - we shall see in the next few years, the fruition of many industrial projects, some of them of a size exceeding anything that we have hitherto attained. The activities connected with offshore oil exploration in the waters of the Archipelago are likely to give rise to a number of interesting manufacturing and service industries based in Singapore.

The problem we are likely to encounter between now and 1975, barring a recession of course, is to provide the large numbers and wide varieties of skills which the new industries will need. In this connection, we have had the advantage of a recent study by Dr Albert Winsemius who led the first United Nations mission in 1960 to Singapore to advise on policies on industrial development. Dr Winsemius is an old friend of Singapore; in 1967 he was awarded the Distinguished Service Medal. Dr Winsemius pays regular visits to the Republic, at our request, to check on our economic health and to discern problems ahead and suggest remedies.

As regards the demand for technicians, who have to support the efforts of engineers, the position is even worse. University Development

    This discussion of the ways in which we should try to fill the gap between demand and supply of engineers leads me to two related subjects. The first relates to the levels of scientific knowledge and technological know-how which our future industries are likely to demand. The second concerns University development in Singapore in general as well as the output of scientists, engineers and technicians in particular.

    In recent months, there has been increasing reference in public as well as private discussions to the need for Singapore to develop "science-based and technology-oriented industries". A well-known British financial commentator recently said that whenever he hears the phrase "advanced industrial technology" he reaches for his gun. Too often this catch phrase is used as an attempt to mulct the public purse of sizable subsidies to finance industrial research which has no hope of resulting in commercially feasible -products. I have a great deal of sympathy for this position, but for different reasons. The use of the term to our industries, existing as well as potential, is often misleading. As an -example, the electronics industry in America works at the frontiers of science and technology. The electronic components we make in Singapore probably require less skill than that required by barbers or cooks, consisting mostly of repetitive manual operations.

    Let us not presume that at the comparatively low level of scientific and technological know-how that we find ourselves today, it is our role to train scientists and engineers who will engage in research at the frontiers of -knowledge.

    Ours should be the more mundane, if practical, approach. In the foreseeable future, we are likely to set up those industrial activities which require assiduous application of engineering skills

Further, not all countries would favour a policy whereby the techniques which they have evolved as a result of sustained and costly research and development work are passed on to others.
